title: Braves manager Brian Snitker's huge risk pays off in Game 2 win vs. Cardinals
text:
CLOSE

ATLANTA — At the moment Adam Duvall emerged from the dugout to pinch hit Friday, a decision that meant pitcher Mike Foltynewicz was officially finished with Game 2 of the National League Division Series, the Atlanta Braves’ starter pretended that the noise he heard from 42,911 fans at SunTrust Park was something like, “Duuuuuuuuuv!”

“That has to be in someone’s head out there,” Foltynewicz said.

It wasn’t. Not even close.

What was in the heads of Braves fans at that very moment was a sense of dread that manager Brian Snitker had just made a horrible mistake, and perhaps there was good reason for that.

Foltynewicz, to that point, had put together the game of his career, cruising through seven innings against the St. Louis Cardinals with just 81 pitches, while the Braves clung to a 1-0 lead in a game they absolutely needed.

And though Snitker has done nothing but win the last two years with a very young team, he has somehow hasn't earned benefit of the doubt from Braves fans, for whom second-guessing his lineup decisions and bullpen moves is a sport unto itself.

So when fans realized Foltynewicz wasn’t going back out for the eighth inning, they let Snitker know what they thought about that particular decision: They booed.

“It was a boo-yay moment,” Snitker said.

The yay, officially, was for Duvall crushing a 3-2 pitch from Jack Flaherty into center field, scoring two more runs that added a huge security blanket for the Braves in a 3-0 victory. It was for Atlanta evening the series at 1-1 when they could have instead gone to St. Louis down 0-2. And it was for a manager with a lower-than-it-should-be approval rating pulling all the right levers, even at times when he left himself open to criticism had it not worked out.

“I’s tension, it’s stress,” Snitker said. “Sometimes I sit in that dugout and wonder like, 'man, we choose to do this?' It’s unbelievable to me sometimes.”

If you were to do a Twitter search for “Snitker” during any Braves game, you’d be led to believe he’s an anti-analytics rube, a mangler of pitching matchups and someone who is generally in over his head as a major-league manager.

The basis for these claims is generally pretty thin, given that he’s overseen a pretty steady progression from complete rebuild to surprise playoff team to legitimate World Series contender. But because Snitker has essentially spent his whole career in the Braves organization, managing teams at all levels of their farm system, there is nothing particularly alluring about him.

When he was chosen in May of 2016 to become the Braves’ interim manager, most people thought it would be a four-month deal and he’d get replaced by someone with a more glamorous background. Instead, he’s kept the job and kept the job, and everyone waiting for him to lose it has been made to look silly.

But still, pro sports isn’t a safe space for coaches. And every big decision like the ones Snitker made Friday potentially has consequences.

“In today’s world everybody wants to be a manager, everybody wants to get caught up in that and we forget about the actual players who are out there performing,” Braves catcher Brian McCann said. “Duvall is an unbelievable bat off the bench, and when you’ve got the arms in the back of your bullpen, you can flip a coin.”

Adam Duvall delivered a pinch-hit two-run homer in the seventh. (Photo: Dale Zanine, USA TODAY Sports)

On one hand, it would have been real easy to let Foltynewicz bat in that situation. He hadn’t walked anyone, had only thrown 81 pitches and the Braves’ relief pitchers had been bad in Game 1. Plus, it wasn’t a situation where the odds of scoring were particularly good with two outs and veteran catcher Brian McCann out there on first.

But while #BravesTwitter was yelling and screaming either for Foltynewicz to pitch or for McCann to be replaced with a pinch runner, Snitker stuck to his playbook. He felt like McCann was too valuable to remove from the game, and he recalled that Duvall had previously hit a home run off Flaherty. So when the Braves got a runner on base, Snitker had no qualms about trying to add a run and handing the game to his bullpen.

“Just how (Foltynewicz) finished the seventh, you know, I’m kinda like, ‘He did his job,’” Snitker said. “He did exactly what we needed him to do and it was a hot day, an emotional day. Not to say you know what you’re going to do day-to-day but you’ve still got something going right there. If you get a single you have the top of your order rolling around. I just felt like he did exactly what we needed him to do in that game.”

Obviously, it paid off in a big way and Foltynewicz – who isn’t good at the plate, to put it mildly – had completely bought into the plan, even though he said he was physically ready to go back out there.

“We wanted to get a real at-bat instead of my poor stuff,” Foltynewicz said. “And it worked out beautifully.”

At least for one night, it did, which only means that the Braves go to St. Louis tied 1-1 in the best-of-five instead of down 2-0. What it doesn’t mean is that Snitker’s decisions will come up aces next time, or that fans will stop turning his name into a curse word on social media.

But when it really mattered to get the Braves back in this series, Snitker was right and the fans booing him were wrong.
description: With his starting pitcher looking unhittable, Braves manager Brian Snitker made the move to pinch-hit in the seventh inning.
